com.larkwoodlabs.net.ip.ipv6
Class IPv6FragmentHeader

java.lang.Object
  com.larkwoodlabs.util.logging.LoggableBase
      com.larkwoodlabs.util.buffer.BufferBackedObject
          com.larkwoodlabs.net.ip.IPExtensionHeader
              com.larkwoodlabs.net.ip.ipv6.IPv6FragmentHeader
All Implemented Interfaces:
IPMessage, Loggable
public final class IPv6FragmentHeader
extends IPExtensionHeader

Represents an IPv6 fragment header. A fragment header is used by an IPv6 source to send packets larger than would fit in the path MTU. A Fragment header is identified by a Next Header value of 44 in the immediately preceding header.

Header Format

   0               1               2               3          
  +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
  |  Next Header  |   Reserved    |      Fragment Offset    |Res|M|
  +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
  |                         Identification                        |
  +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
Next Header

Identifies the initial header type of the Fragmentable Part of the original packet (defined below). Uses the same values as the IPv4 Protocol field [RFC-1700 et seq.].

See IPExtensionHeader.getNextProtocolNumber(), IPExtensionHeader.getNextMessage(), IPExtensionHeader.setNextMessage(IPMessage).

Reserved

Reserved field. Initialized to zero for transmission; ignored on reception.

Fragment Offset

The offset, in 8-octet units, of the data following this header, relative to the start of the Fragmentable Part of the original packet.

See getFragmentOffset(), setFragmentOffset(short).

Reserved (Res)

Reserved field. Initialized to zero for transmission; ignored on reception.

More Fragments (M) Flag

   1 = more fragments;
   0 = last fragment.

See getMoreFragments(), setMoreFragments(boolean).

Identification

For every packet that is to be fragmented, the source node generates an Identification value. The Identification must be different than that of any other fragmented packet sent recently* with the same Source Address and Destination Address. If a Routing header is present, the Destination Address of concern is that of the final destination.

See getIdentification(), setIdentification(int).

Author:
Gregory Bumgardner (gbumgard)
